articles.headline: Rich Americans Snap Up Irish Castles for Love and Discounts
articles.snippet: Many with deep pockets and traceable Irish roots pay cash to buy castles and manor houses at bargain rates.
articles.abstract: Many with deep pockets and traceable Irish roots pay cash to buy castles and manor houses at bargain rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: FIRST-TIME visitors to Humewood Castle in Kiltegan, County Wicklow, can’t help it. They simply say, “Wow.”

articles.headline: Advisers Go Extra Lengths to Keep Wealthy Clients
articles.snippet: Firms have offered concierge services, space for family meetings or compilation of family histories.
articles.abstract: Firms have offered concierge services, space for family meetings or compilation of family histories.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAREN McNEILL has a Ph.D. in history from the University of California, Berkeley, and is considered one of the foremost authorities on Julia Morgan, the architect who designed Hearst Castle, William Randolph Hearst’s 90,000-square-foot coastal retreat. Ms. McNeill has written extensively about Morgan, who designed some 700 buildings and helped open the field of architecture to women.

articles.headline: Twitter Reports Sharp Rise in Revenue
articles.snippet: Twitter reported in an amended prospectus for its initial public offering that its revenue surged in the third quarter and that the number of its users had increased.
articles.abstract: Twitter reported in an amended prospectus for its initial public offering that its revenue surged in the third quarter and that the number of its users had increased.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Twitter prepares to hit the road to begin peddling its stock to the public, the company disclosed new revenue numbers on Tuesday that may help it persuade investors to buy the shares.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: JPMorgan Expected to Admit Fault in ‘London Whale’ Trading Loss
articles.snippet: Aside from admitting some wrongdoing, the bank is expected to pay about $100 million to resolve the case with Commodity Futures Trading Commission as soon as this week.
articles.abstract: Aside from admitting some wrongdoing, the bank is expected to pay about $100 million to resolve the case with Commodity Futures Trading Commission as soon as this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:25 p.m. | For JPMorgan Chase, fines totaling billions of dollars are no longer sufficient to placate the government. Now the bank’s regulators want something stiffer: a mea culpa.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Stalemate Puts Strain on a Vital Debt Market
articles.snippet: The continuing sell-off in Treasuries, a by-product of the impasse in Congress, could disrupt the so-called repo market, making it hard for investment banks to operate.
articles.abstract: The continuing sell-off in Treasuries, a by-product of the impasse in Congress, could disrupt the so-called repo market, making it hard for investment banks to operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the financial crisis of 2008, the vast and shadowy machinery of the financial system seized up, making a bad situation worse.

articles.headline: With G.O.P. Badly Divided, Boehner Is Left ‘Herding Cats’
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner finds himself at a crossroads: an imminent financial default on the one hand, and on the other an unyielding conservative rank and file.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner finds himself at a crossroads: an imminent financial default on the one hand, and on the other an unyielding conservative rank and file.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After House Republicans began their closed-door meeting on Tuesday with an impromptu rendition of “Amazing Grace,” Speaker John A. Boehner stood up with what he hoped would be an equally inspiring message.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Imagining the Dollar Without Its Privilege
articles.snippet: It is inevitable that the dollar will gradually lose its position as the world’s reserve currency, no matter what happens in Congress.
articles.abstract: It is inevitable that the dollar will gradually lose its position as the world’s reserve currency, no matter what happens in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember the last time the country came to the brink of default? It was August 2011. For the first time in history, Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, downgraded United States government debt.

articles.headline: Real Estate Heating Up in Indonesia
articles.snippet: Officials, brokers and developers are debating whether resurgent commercial and residential real estate markets are a cause for jubilation or concern.
articles.abstract: Officials, brokers and developers are debating whether resurgent commercial and residential real estate markets are a cause for jubilation or concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Gita Wirjawan, Indonesia’s trade minister, made a steeply rising motion with his right hand, like an airplane soaring into the sky, when asked about the surging real estate market in this country. “Scary, isn’t it?” he said.

articles.headline: Viewing U.S. in Fear and Dismay
articles.snippet: The world has reacted mostly with disbelief that a superpower could fall into such dysfunction.
articles.abstract: The world has reacted mostly with disbelief that a superpower could fall into such dysfunction.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The word many Mexicans now use to describe Washington reflects a familiar mix of outrage and exasperation: berrinche. Technically defined as a tantrum, berrinches are also spoiled little rich kids, blind to their privilege and the effects of their misbehavior.

articles.headline: Republicans Back Down, Ending Crisis Over Shutdown and Debt Limit
articles.snippet: President Obama swiftly signed a bill funding the government through Jan. 15 and raising the debt limit through Feb. 7. after Senate talks produced a deal amounting to a near total defeat for conservatives.
articles.abstract: President Obama swiftly signed a bill funding the government through Jan. 15 and raising the debt limit through Feb. 7. after Senate talks produced a deal amounting to a near total defeat for conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans conceded defeat on Wednesday in their bitter budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law as the House and Senate approved last-minute legislation ending a disruptive 16-day government shutdown and extending federal borrowing power to avert a financial default with potentially worldwide economic repercussions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: A Regulator Cuts New Teeth on JPMorgan in ‘London Whale’ Case
articles.snippet: Wall Street is feeling the effects of a Commodity Futures Trading Commission rule it fought hard to tame.
articles.abstract: Wall Street is feeling the effects of a Commodity Futures Trading Commission rule it fought hard to tame.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | Lobbying groups for Wall Street’s biggest banks cautioned that a new rule before the nation’s commodities trading regulator “could have myriad unintended adverse consequences.” A hedge fund trade group feared that the rule was “overly aggressive.” And the CME Group, one of the world’s largest futures exchanges, warned that the rule was susceptible to legal action.

articles.headline: Investors Cheer Deal to End Shutdown but Worry About Reruns
articles.snippet: Many investors were left worrying that the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years could spin on endlessly.
articles.abstract: Many investors were left worrying that the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years could spin on endlessly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | While investors were cheered on Wednesday by a last-minute agreement to raise the nation’s borrowing limit and end the government shutdown, their relief was tempered by the knowledge that the deal was far from a permanent solution. And they were tabulating what the long-term costs of the political turmoil could be.
